name: clinker production | clinker | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10748/documentation

This activity represents the production of clinker.;;;Clinker is a constituant of Portland cement. It is produced by heating (sintering) limestone and clay in a cement kiln.;Other raw materials are added in the mixture to be sintered, but in smaller quantities. ; ;In its 2005 document (Cement and Structural Concrete products LCI for Canadian cement mills) , Athena Institute, mention that "other ipunt materials" may include steel mill scale (iron oxides consisting of iron(II,III) oxide, hematite, and magnetite); iron slag or iron ore residue may also be used in small amounts to adjust the formulation to achieve the desired iron content. Similarly, bauxite or even aluminum scrap may be added to adjust Al2O3 levels, and sand is often used as a supplementary source of silica. However, because these inputs (excluding marl) are less than 1% of the total material input and because they make only minor contributions to emissions or residuals, these are typically not reported by plants.;;At the kiln exit, ckinker is in the form of lumps or nodules, usually 3-25 mm in diameter. A grinding step is necessary in order for it to be ready for cement production.

From reception of materials at the cement plant gate.

This activity ends with the clinker ready for production of cement mix. 
The dataset includes the whole manufacturing process to produce clinker (raw material provision, grinding and mixing; Long dry and Pre-calciner kiln process), internal processes (transport, etc.).
The dataset does not include administration activities. 
In this version of the dataset, waste used as fuel and raw material enter the system without environmental burdens from upstream processes. Only the emissions from its combustion are included.
The following inputs were excluded (per kg clinker):
- "Other input materials": 1,09E-02 kg
- Waste - other solid / Misc. : 3,59E-03 kg
- Residual oil: 1,22 E-03 kg
- Used tyres: 5,30E-3kg
- Spent solvent mixture: 1,58E-03 kg
- Spent oil and grease mixture: 3,53E-03kg (assuming 0,9 kg/litre)
Also, the Canadian National Pollutant Release Inventory 2007 lists the following as inorganic (not metals) materials transferred for recycling / recovery:
- Chromium (and its compounds): 7,49 E-6 kg/kg clinker
- Manganese (and its compounds): 1,15 E-6 kg/kg clinker
- Nickel (and its compounds): 3,01 E-7 kg/kg clinker
These by-products were excluded from the dataset because of their small amounts and lack of specificity.
Finally, "Other input materials" listed in literature sources  (see General Comment field for details) are excluded because their individual amounts are unknown. Values from the generic (GLO) clinker production dataset (ecoinvent v3.0) were used for ammonia and bauxite.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2394:Manufacture of cement, lime and plaster

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Average production volume over 2008-2011.;Inventory data provided for 2007, the uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Typical technology for  Quebec production (including Long dry and Pre-calciner kilns).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Energy inputs are based on "US and Canadian Labor-Energy Input Survey 2007" (Portland Cement Association, 2008). It is assumed that Québec cement plants are equivalent to North American cement plants in terms of energy consumption.
Calculations are based on two important technical parameters for the Canadian Cement Plants, by Athena Institute:
1. an equivalent finished cement ton is composed of 92% clinker and 8% finished cement ;
2.Capacity utilisation rate of the cement plant is assumed to be 93.3%
Emissions to air are based on a weighted average of 3 Quebec cement plants.
Emissions to water: data from one (1) Quebec cement plant. It's the only Canadian cement plant that has reported "emissions to water" to the Canadian National Pollutant Release Inventory in 2007.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Several published sources were used to elaborate this dataset:
- For energy input: Based on "US and Canadian Labor-Energy Input Survey 2007" (Portland Cement Association, 2008) data (in which Québec cement mills are included). An average energy input profile of Canadian mills is used (see Extrapolations field below)
- For material inputs: Based on "Cement and Structural Concrete Products LCI" (Athena Institute, 2005) data (Table 3.1). Values regarding Quebec plants (Eastern Region) were used, updated with Athena LCI database 2013 for some constituents.
- For water input: Based on US and Canadian 2007 labor-energy input survey data, and "LCI of Portland Cement Manufacture" (PCA, 2006). 
- For emissions to air and water: Based on Canadian National Pollutant Release Inventory (2007) data, covering all the cement plants. When a substance was not reported by Québec plants, the generic (GLO) value from ecoinvent v.3.0 clinker production dataset was used, the uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
- For solid waste: Based on Athena 2005 cement LCI data (Table 7.3).
